sections.title: Description
sections.content:
Among the oldest and most revered deities of Mesoamerica, Tlaloc was the god of rain, fertility, and water.
                Predating the Aztecs by millennia, his goggle-eyed visage appears in the ruins of Teotihuacan. He brought
                the life-giving rains that made agriculture possible, but also the devastating floods, hail, and lightning
                that could destroy crops and lives. His paradise, Tlalocan, awaited those who died by water or lightning.

name: Aztec - Tlaloc

subtitle: Tlaloc- "He Who Makes Things Sprout" / "Earth"

hoverInfo.quick: Among the oldest and most revered deities of Mesoamerica, Tlaloc was the god of rain, fertility, and...

thirdSun.title: Lord of the Third Sun
thirdSun.narrative: In the Aztec creation cycle, Tlaloc presided over the Third Sun (Third World Age) called Nahui Quiahuitl ('Four Rain'). During this age, the world was destroyed by a rain of fire - some say volcanic eruptions, others a rain of burning stones from the sky. The survivors were transformed into turkeys, dogs, and butterflies.
thirdSun.significance: Demonstrates Tlaloc's dual nature as giver and destroyer

tlalocan.title: Tlalocan - Paradise of the Rain God
tlalocan.narrative: Tlaloc rules over Tlalocan, one of the Aztec afterlife realms. Unlike the bleak underworld of Mictlan, Tlalocan is described as a verdant paradise of eternal spring, abundant with food, flowers, and gentle rains. Those who die by drowning, lightning strike, water-related diseases (like dropsy), or leprosy are taken directly to this paradise rather than journeying to Mictlan.
tlalocan.significance: Provides an alternative afterlife for those claimed by water

tlaloque.title: The Tlaloque - Rain Servants
tlaloque.narrative: Tlaloc commands the Tlaloque (also called Tepictoton), a host of smaller rain deities associated with mountains, clouds, and bodies of water. Each mountain had its own tlaloque, which stored rain in great jars. When Tlaloc commanded, they would break their jars with their lightning staffs, releasing rain. The type of rain depended on which jar was broken - some brought gentle, nourishing rain; others brought hail, frost, or floods.
tlaloque.significance: Explains the different types of precipitation and their sources

ancientOrigins.teotihuacan: Goggle-eyed rain god present in 200-750 CE murals
ancientOrigins.narrative: Tlaloc is among the most ancient deities of Mesoamerica, his worship predating the Aztecs by over a thousand years. His distinctive goggle-eyed, fanged face appears in the murals and sculptures of Teotihuacan (circa 100 CE - 750 CE), the great city that influenced all later Mesoamerican cultures.
ancientOrigins.aztecAdoption: When the Aztecs rose to power, they inherited this ancient rain god and elevated him to supreme importance. He shared the great Templo Mayor with Huitzilopochtli - representing the two pillars of Aztec civilization: agriculture and war.

                that could destroy crops and lives. His paradise, Tlalocan, awaited those who died by water or lightning.

childSacrifice.description: The Aztecs believed that the tears of children would call forth Tlaloc's rain. During droughts or at specific festival times, children (especially those with distinctive features like birthmarks or double cowlicks) were sacrificed to Tlaloc.
childSacrifice.method: They were often decorated with jade, blue flowers, and feathers before being led to mountain shrines or drowned in Lake Texcoco.
childSacrifice.belief: The more the children cried, the more effective the sacrifice was believed to be.

atlcahualoFestival.title: The Atlcahualo Festival
atlcahualoFestival.timing: The first month of the Aztec calendar
atlcahualoFestival.description: During Atlcahualo ('Stopping of Water'), children were sacrificed at seven different locations around the Valley of Mexico, particularly at mountain shrines where clouds gathered.

formsOfWorship.description: Tears were believed to invoke rain
Jade, rubber balls, copal incense, blue flowers, and food
Temples on peaks where clouds formed naturally
Ceremonies at lakes, springs, and cenotes

cosmology.cardinalDirection: East - where rain clouds form over the Gulf
cosmology.sacredMountain: Mount Tlaloc, where his main shrine stood 4,120 meters high
cosmology.mayaEquivalent: Chaac / Chac (Maya rain god with similar goggle eyes)

iconography.goggleEyes: His most distinctive feature - circular rings around the eyes, possibly representing rain clouds, water, or serpent coils
iconography.fangedMouth: Often depicted with jaguar fangs or serpent elements, representing his dual nature as both life-giver and destroyer
iconography.waterJar: Shown holding jars filled with different types of rain - beneficial rains, storms, hail, or floods
iconography.lightningStaff: A serpent-shaped staff used to break the water jars and create thunder and lightning

extendedContent.modernSignificance: Tlaloc remains one of the most recognizable figures of pre-Columbian Mexican art. His goggle-eyed visage appears on countless ancient artifacts and continues to influence Mexican art and identity. A massive stone sculpture of Tlaloc, weighing 168 tons, was controversially moved from the town of Coatlinchan to Mexico City in 1964, where it now stands outside the National Museum of Anthropology. Local legend claims that on the day the statue was moved, a massive rainstorm struck Mexico City despite it being the dry season - as if Tlaloc was expressing his displeasure. This story reflects the ongoing cultural connection between modern Mexicans and their ancient religious heritage. In indigenous communities that maintain traditional practices, offerings to rain and mountain spirits continue, representing an unbroken thread connecting contemporary Mexico to its Mesoamerican past.

archetypes.name: Rain/Storm God
archetypes.description: Tlaloc embodies the Rain God archetype - controller of life-giving waters and destructive storms, essential for agricultural civilization.

primarySources: Diego Duran's Book of the Gods
Archaeological evidence from Teotihuacan, Templo Mayor, and Mount Tlaloc

periods.description: Goggle-eyed rain god in Olmec and Teotihuacan cultures
Similar deity Chaac in parallel Maya civilization
Crucial agricultural deity for valley farming

calendarAssociations.agricultural: Rain god festivals tied to maize planting cycles
calendarAssociations.significance: Tlaloc rituals essential for Lake Texcoco valley agriculture

preColumbian.name: Teotihuacan murals and glyphs
preColumbian.content: Evidence of goggle-eyed rain deity predating Aztecs

primary.name: Templo Mayor - Tlaloc Shrine (North)
primary.description: Dual pyramid with dedicated Tlaloc temple, shared with Huitzilopochtli
primary.findings: Blue-painted vessels, jade offerings, water-related iconography

secondary.name: Teotihuacan Citadel
secondary.description: Pyramid of Quetzalcoatl with Tlaloc representations

secondary.name: Malinalco
secondary.description: Mountain shrine temple possibly with rain god cult

primary.victim: Children sacrificed at mountain shrines (like Tlaloc's Tlalocan paradise)
primary.purpose: Petition for rain and agricultural fertility

primary.method: Drowning in Lake Texcoco or heart extraction
primary.purpose: Ensure rain cycles for maize, beans, amaranth

sacrificialRites.significance: Tlalocan (Tlaloc's paradise) was destination for those who died by water/lightning

ancientContinuity.teotihuacan: Goggle-eyed rain god present in 200-750 CE murals
ancientContinuity.olmec: Rain deity concepts may trace to Olmec (1500-400 BCE)
ancientContinuity.maya: Parallel deity Chaac shows widespread Mesoamerican rain god tradition

_methodologyNotes: Calendar associations verified against primary codex sources
Codex sources include primary Spanish colonial records and native nahuatl/maya texts
Archaeological sites documented from excavation reports and academic publications
Sacrificial rituals documented from Florentine Codex and validated against archaeological evidence
